classes.name: Introduction to College Writing
classes.description: ENG-131 is the first college-level composition course in a two-semester sequence. Students will be introduced to writing, reading, critical thinking, and using information at the college level. In particular, the course will help students develop writing that reveals rhetorical and academic flexibility.
classes.subject: English

classes.name: Introduction to Psychology
classes.description: Introduces elementary concepts and principles related to the scientific study of behavior and of the mental processes of cognition and affective states. Variables examined include the history of psychology, the scientific method, theory, biological foundations, psychological processes related to cognition and affective states, developmental changes over time, and applications related to healthy and unhealthy personalities.
classes.personalNote: This class was my first ever college level course. It was very intense, the grading was tough and the exams were very high level. I made it out passing but I'm glad most classes aren't like this.
classes.subject: Social Science

classes.name: Introduction to Information Technology
classes.description: Survey the field of computer technology and information management.
classes.personalNote: This class was a bit of a sore spot for me. The professor graded everything on the last day grades were do and never responded to my emails. Content wise the course was simple, Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and my first intro into databases
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Precalculus
classes.description: Topics include algebraic, graphical and numerical representations of functions, including composition and inverses of functions. Focuses on the study of rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, and trigonometric functions of real numbers and angles. Also includes analytic trigonometry and solutions of triangles. Techniques of problem solving and applications are included throughout the course requiring the frequent usage of graphing calculators.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Intro to Sociology
classes.description: Introduces the sociological approach to understanding culture and society. Examines human behavior in a group context, focusing on the prominent influence of culture and social structure on individuals. Connections between individuals and a variety of social institutions, such as the economy, government, and mass media, are examined and compared in U.S. society and on a global scale. Focuses on cultural diversity and social inequalities, such as those related to class, race, ethnicity and gender.
classes.personalNote: This is one of my favorite courses I have ever taken. It almost convinced me to change my major from computer science to sociology. I realised I could do more good being a computer science major with a basic knowledge of sociology than a sociology major with a basic knowledge of computer science. I hope to see my skills work in the sociology study space.
classes.subject: Social Science

classes.name: Principles of Programming Logic
classes.description: An introductory-level course presenting programming logic concepts and skills. Emphasizes structured methods of programming. Covers input, output, selection/decisions, loops, arrays, data validation, functions, and modules. A computer lab is used for debugging, compilation and testing.
classes.personalNote: This course was very basic. I had a background in everything that was taught due to some high school computer science classes. Was offered to skip the class but had scheduling conflictions.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Intro to the Study of Religion
classes.subject: Social Science

classes.name: Calculus I
classes.description: Topics include limits, continuity, the derivative, differentiation of algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions, applications of the derivative, antidifferentiation, and the definite integral. Numerical, graphical and algebraic approaches are used whenever possible.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: SQL for Database Development
classes.description: An intermediate-level course familiarizing the student with the SQL language used to retrieve and modify tables and data within a SQL Server database management system. Covers outer joins, summary queries, and subqueries. Also discusses using normalization techniques to design and create database structures, views, scripts, stored procedures, scalar functions, and triggers.
classes.personalNote: For a 100 level CIS course this was very in depth. This class made my 4000 level university course feel like review. This course also gave me a lot of SQL knowledge which has been very prevalent in my internship experience
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: C Programming
classes.description: An intermediate-level course which familiarizes the student with the C programming language. Covers designing, coding, testing, and debugging programs. Emphasizes program and coding efficiency.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Engineering Physics I
classes.description: Emphasizes relating physical principles to mathematical techniques in problem solving. Covers mechanics, wave motion, and thermodynamics.
classes.subject: Physical Science

classes.name: Descriptive Astronomy
classes.description: Consists of a non-mathematical introduction to elements of the astronomical universe by means of lecture and planetarium demonstrations. Covers the major units of the universe and their interrelation. Scientific background not necessary.
classes.subject: Physical Science

classes.name: C++ Programming
classes.description: An advanced-level course expanding upon arrays, pointers, structures, templates, and file I/O. Test Driven Development (TDD), refactoring, and UML diagrams concepts are applied. Covers theory and application in areas such as the standard template libraries including vectors, lists, stacks, queues, sets, and maps. Object oriented principles of classes, data, inheritance and dynamic binding are covered.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Bus & Tech Writing & Research
classes.description: ENG-135 focuses on the Critical Thinking & Information Literacy and the Written Communication Institutional Learning Outcomes. Students design documents such as resumes, letters, memos, instructions, proposals, and an extensive, research-based documented report for the kinds of readers they will address as professionals. This course should be especially valuable for students pursuing careers in business, computer science, automotive technology, allied health, and other technical fields.
classes.subject: English

classes.name: Discrete Mathematics
classes.description: Covers logic, methods of proof, set theory, algorithms, recursion, correctness, relations, partial orderings, graphs, trees, Boolean algebra, grammars, and finite-state machines. Includes various applications throughout the course.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Religious Traditions in the World
classes.description: Introduces the beliefs, practices, and experiences of the major world religious traditions. In addition to examining the particulars of each faith, this course emphasizes current perspectives in religious studies that serve to clarify the nature and functions of religion as a force shaping, and being shaped by, the increasingly pluralistic contemporary world. Religion will be treated seriously as an important part of people's identity and a crucial prerequisite for understanding and appreciating others and selves.
classes.subject: Social Science

classes.name: Arduino Microcontroller
classes.description: Core principles of engineering practice: design, teamwork, professional ethics.
classes.personalNote: The description is not very good for this class. This class covered the basics of microcontrollers using a Ardruino UNO. We used physical componenets as well as simulations. Overall very fun and informative class.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Python Programming and Computation
classes.description: Basic control structures (sequence, selection, repetition) and all core data types using objects. Practice on core data structures (string, list, tuple, dictionary, and set). Design, implementation and testing of programs to solve problems with an emphasis on data manipulation using real world, practical examples.
classes.personalNote: For a beginner level class this covered a lot of material and overall was a fun experience. Some of my favorite topics included introduction to graphics, handling JSON data and API's, and data clustering using CSV earthquake data.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Java Programming
classes.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of programming using Java. Topics include: object-oriented programming, classes, constructors, flow control statements, data types, methods, inheritance, data hiding, abstraction, exceptions, file I/O, Java GUI, and Java packages.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Calculus II
classes.description: Review definition of definite integral and fundamental theorem of calculus. Techniques of integration; approximate integration; improper integrals; applications of integration. Sequences and series. Approximating functions by polynomials and Taylor series.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Probability and Statistics
classes.description: Core principles of engineering practice: design, teamwork, professional ethics.
classes.personalNote: This class also doesn't have a good description. We covered topics which included Probability, Discrete and Continous Random Variables, Sampling, Hypothesis Testing, Design of Experienments, and a introduction to the MiniTab Software. This class was poorely managed due to a last minute switch of professors and then a switch back meaning their was 3 different versions of the syllabus. Due to these problems this class was switched to PASS/FAIL.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Computer Science II
classes.description: Design and implementation of fundamental abstract data types of computer science (such as stacks, queues, trees, lists, hashing, and graphs), using an object-oriented language. Programming requirements include the implementation of abstract data types using arrays and dynamic links; recursion; sorting and searching; hashing; and string processing. Introduction to algorithm analysis.
classes.personalNote: This class is a one of the two weeder classes at Wayne State. This class had a heavy course load from designing most of the Data Structures from scratch in C++ (which can be seen on my github) and Mathmatical analysis of these structures.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Contemporary Moral Issues
classes.description: Critical discussion of contemporary moral issues including pornography, adultery, same-sex marriage, abortion, preferential treatment, obligations to the poor, capital punishment, terrorism, and others.
classes.subject: Social Science

classes.name: Ethics in Computer Science
classes.description: Students will study the ethical and legal issues that arise with the usage and development of computing technology. Students will learn the responsibilities of the computer professionals and how to make appropriate decisions when faced with legal and ethical issues in computing.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Data Science Life Cycle
classes.description: State of the art research, development and practice topics from across the fields of engineering; emphasis on interdisciplinary topics.
classes.personalNote: This class was a very interesting introduction into data science. Though this class was not mathmatical, it went into the business decisions and engineering politics that goes into a data science project taught by the VP of Data Science at GM Financial.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Algorithm Design and Analysis
classes.description: Formal techniques to support design and analysis of algorithms: underlying mathematical theory and practical considerations of efficiency. Topics include asymptotic complexity bounds, techniques of analysis, algorithmic strategies, advanced data and file structures, and introduction to automata theory and its application to language translation.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Introduction to Database Management Systems
classes.description: Topics include: database concepts, ER modeling, schemas and constraints, SQL and relational algebra, web-based database applications, triggers and views, physical organization and indexing, query processing, query optimization, NoSQL databases.
classes.personalNote:
A better title for this class would be Full Stack Deveolpement. We learned the most about databases but we also had extensive work in PHP and Front End Technologies. My group's full stack TODO List app is on my GitHub here https://github.com/nickwfarkas/TODO-List.
 Side note if you want to know what work is mine. I created all the PHP files that ended in the word request and all of the front end.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Introduction to Theoretical Computer Science
classes.description: Finite automata and regular expressions; context-free grammars; pushdown automata; Turing machines; hierarchy of formal languages and automata; computability and decidability.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Statistical Computing and Data Analysis
classes.description: Computational aspect of statistics and data analysis for advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate students. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, hypothesis testing, ANOVA, linear regression and logistic regression. Data analysis by use of statistical packages such as R, SAS, Python, SPSS or Minitab.
classes.personalNote: As well as a refresher on itermediate statistical topics. We did all class assignments and analysis using the R language. If you are curious to see my final project on whether there is a relationship between crime rate and state government political party. There is my data, code, and graphs on my GitHub here https://github.com/nickwfarkas/STAT-5030. Along with a video of me presenting my analysis here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JU4YucMDLLc&t=53s.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Technical Communication II: Presentations
classes.description: Instruction in basic technical presentation skills. Requirements include informative presentations, oral briefings, needs assessments, progress reports, and formal proposals. Topics include collaborative teamwork, audience and purpose analysis, textual and visual aspects of presentation design, and formatting.
classes.personalNote: This class was very group based meaning that the final grade very much depended on your group not your own individual contributions.
classes.subject: English

classes.name: Computer Architecture and Organization
classes.description: Organization and architecture of computer systems. Topics include: digital logic and digital systems; machine-level representation of data and programs; assembly level machine organization and programming; register-level description of computer execution and the functional organization of a computer; role and function of programming languages, libraries and operating systems; performance evaluation; systems programming.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
classes.description: Best case, worst case, and expected case complexity analysis; asymptotic approximations; solutions of recurrence equations; probabilistic techniques; divide-and-conquer; the greedy approach; dynamic programming; branch and bound; NP-completeness; parallel algorithms.
classes.personalNote: First Graduate Level class taken at Wayne State University.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Introduction to Data Science
classes.description: An applied statistical learning course designed for upper level undergraduate students and graduate students in mathematics and other quantitative fields. Topics include: bias-variance trade-off, regression, classification, cross-validation, bootstrap, model selection, regularization, splines, generalized additive models, tree-based methods, support vector machines, principal component analysis and clustering. Computer implementation will be discussed for each of the methods, and students will run their own data analysis projects.
classes.personalNote: One of my favorite classes of ny college career thus far. We learned many different machine learnning models and validation techniques from the math to the R implementation. We also spent time learning neural networks which wasn't in the class description. For the final project I created a neural network that rated songs like a famous Youtube song critic. My presentation can be seen on Youtube here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FsI3pIgVHeE.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Software Engineering
classes.description: Software life cycle; software requirement analysis; software system design; software implementation and testing; software maintenance; team programming; ethics and programmers.
classes.personalNote: This class acted not only as a software lifecycle class as well as a advanced python class, covering advanced python topics while creating large scale projects for hypothetical companies. Creating projects that utilitzed tKinter desktop development, Pygame game development, and sklearn machine learning.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Calculus III
classes.description: Multivariable calculus with applications. Vectors and vector functions in two and three dimensions; functions of several variables; differentiation; integration; vector calculus.
classes.subject: Math

classes.name: Computer Operating Systems
classes.description: Operating system services; file systems; CPU scheduling; memory management; virtual memory; disk scheduling; deadlocks; concurrent processes.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Digital Image Processing and Analysis
classes.description: Review of image formation and acquisition; image transformation; image enhancement and restoration; image compression; morphological image processing; edge detection and segmentation; architecture for image processing.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Intelligent Systems: Algorithms and Tools
classes.description: Introduction to basic algorithms and software tools for intelligent data representation and analysis, including: data pre-processing, data exploration and visualization, model evaluation, predictive modeling, classification methods, association analysis, clustering, anomaly detection, representing extracted patterns as expertise, tools for data mining and intelligent systems such as WEKA, CLIPS, and MATLAB.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Introduction to Machine Learning and Applications
classes.description: Through algorithmic investigation, brainstorming, and case analysis, students develop the skills and strategies that are necessary for effective leaning from data, including Big Data emerging from science and engineering.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Senior Capstone Project
classes.description: Development of skills for planning, managing, implementing, and documenting complex software projects. Project management techniques; software development teams; data management, privacy, and security.
classes.subject: Computer Science

classes.name: Analytical Physics 2
classes.description: The second in a two-semester sequence of calculus-based physics courses for physical science and engineering students covering calculus-based electromagnetism, electromagnetic waves, and physical and geometrical optics. The student will also perform integrated experiments dealing with the physics of electromagnetism, electromagnetic waves, and physical and geometrical optics.
classes.subject: Physical Science

_attributes: Developed rich UI experiences using Angular and Material design to deliver a simplistic and beautiful solutions for internal business problems.
Created backend solutions using NodeJS to improve API performance.
Worked on a small internal team to develope smart contracts using Solidity and the Ethereum Blockchain.
Developed rich UI experiences using Angular and Material design to deliver a simplistic and beautiful solutions for internal business problems.
Created backend solutions to plug into UI using C# .Net Core, Entity Framework, and SQL.
Worked with team of interns to create a Microsoft Teams bot utilizing C# and Microsoft Developer tools.
Querying, modifying and creating data tables in Salesforce Marketing Cloud using SQL.
Salesforce Marketing Cloud email testing and template creation using Postman.
Assisted marketing team with technical challenges in Salesforce Marketing Cloud.
Assisted in creating Salesforce Marketing Cloud Automations and MuleSoft flows.
C# .Net Core backend development for many different internal applications.
Head of UX design with a team of interns to create an internal education tool for new team members.
Presented iteration recaps that showed our business partners and higher management what features my team have deployed and what they can be expecting to see deployed

Created infrastructure diagrams and code documentation to show how code has been implemented and how infrastructure has been structured to support said code so there can be a seamless transition when a team or team member takes over work on an application.
Unloaded incoming trucks and properly staged inventory for processing.
Loaded outbound trucks by hand or by pallet jacking whole pallets in a safe and efficent manner.

Assisting Associate Product Check In, making sure associates have everything they need to be successful. Clearing conveyor jams and packages that are sent to the wrong location while handling damaged packages safely.

Problem Solving if there was a damaged package or package in incorrect building, I would assess the problem and take care it. Whether I had to re/box, do spill cleanup in which I was hazmat trained, or send a request for a new product for the customer.
Updated filing system by digitizing tax forms and bookkeeping records so the whole company has to rely less on paper filings with more secure, scalable, and reliable digital pdf format.
Corporate QuickBooks bookkeeping throughout year/ending so I could create payroll, income, and other financial analytics for quarterly, semiannual, and annual taxes.

Completed front desk duties such as checking in and out clients, taking payment and handling money, call reception, aid in understanding their tax return and customer service resulting in a seamless tax process for our clients.

_skills._skillDescription: Proficent using the Angular framework to create beautiful, immersive, and responsive UIs.
Proficent using the TypeScript with Angular Framework for front end and NodeJS for backend to write typeable, testable, scalable code for UIs.
Enjoy writting C# when utilizing .Net Core to write APIs.
Experienced writing vanilla JavaScript and JQuery to create small scale web applications but I prefer Typescript to vanilla JavaScript.
Is it a programming language? Is it not?
Just like HTML there is no escaping CSS. Even when I try to escape and use tailwind I always end up writing more than I would like.
I have written a lot of SQL from MySQL, AWS RDS, Access, to Salesforce Marketing Cloud.

Though I have never worked with C++ on a industry application. C++ is my language of choice when solving academic computer science problems from data structures, algorithms, to even a little microcontroller programming.
I have done a lot of school projects in Java and even some high school robotics but have no idustry experience yet.

Out of all the programming languages I have utilized, I have the most academic and personal experience with Python. I have mastered utilizing many of Pythons popular libraies such as sklearn for data modeling, pandas for data processing, tKinter for desktop development and pygame for game development.
I have academic experience utilizing a lot of the tools that R has to offer from basic statistical analysis to Neural Networks. When creating Machine Learning models I perfer to use R over Python.
1% Coding, 99% Merge Conflicts
I have experience testing APIs with Postman as well as creating collections that other Team Members can utilize when testing APIs.

From my first job to my last job I have been working in Excel for years. From bookkeeping to data analysis, I know my way around Excel. I have earned a Microsoft Specialist Certification in Excel as well.
When I learned of the Agile way of looking at projects it changed my whole perspective. Even on my personal projects I always find time for a work board and cutting my tasks into verticle slices.
There was a lot of sweat and even more tears when learning to master Linked Lists, Stacks, Queues, Binary Search Trees, AVL Trees, Hash Tables, Heaps, and Graphs

I understand that the definition of algorithm is just a process or a set of rules which is fair but I have spent a lot of time learning and implementing complex algorithms academicly and in the industry. So I would like to think it's more complicated.

I enjoy creating software and implementing my thoughts but I have always loved seeing my big picture thoughts on paper in the form of Flowcharts, Class Diagrams, Entity Relationship Diagrams, UML, or Network Diagrams.

I have recently started my dive into data science with a minor in statistics. I can properly clean and pre-process data for many machine learning models. Through my coursework I can understand and effectively implement many machine learning algorithms and validate the results.
I first experienced Node using Angular and NPM. I have industry experience across several domains writing and testing server side code with NodeJS using Typescript.
